----- Original Message -----
From: "Lauren Bish" <developerdude@...>


>
> 1) Get an early testing effort started. This is very important. Just get
> something started. If you can't convince management to do TDD, then
convince
> them to do some form of unit testing, even if it isn't the developer
> themselves testing. Later on you can get TDD started at some level.

I should have added that I find it useful to have both TDD and Unit testing
that is done by a dedicated unit tester. Not many developers have the proper
attitude for testing; testing takes a somewhat destructive attitude, while
writing code is a creative process. Also, many developers don't have the
aptitude or expertise for testing. This is not a slam on developers, just a
recognition that testing and developing (both of which I have done) are two
different areas of expertise.

FWIW,
Lauren
